themes: Perceived exclusion and tokenization in funding criteria
Challenges for intersectional and multicultural organizations
Financial precarity and lack of sustainable funding
Emotional toll and discouragement from funding processes
Disconnect between funding requirements and lived experience
key_phrases: COA funding opportunities perpetuate seperation rather than inclusion
My dance company is a melting pot of cultures, and an LGBTQ+ friendly organization
I need to find a way to conform to existing standards that I feel are creating more of the same old issue
I refuse to tokenize members of the LGBTQ+ and their experience to get money
I don't fit the bill of COA requirements either
I do not want to attend cultural events because they make me feel like an outsider
Dance is extremely under supported fiscally in comparison to the other art forms
Our community of supporters are tapped out financially, and I do not have connections to wealthy patrons
The burden of supporting arts and humanities should not fall on the backs of the people
barriers_identified: Funding criteria that require tokenization or strict identity-based justification
Lack of fit with COA requirements for multicultural or intersectional organizations
Dance being underfunded compared to other art forms
Discouragement and emotional toll from repeated funding denials
solutions_proposed: Reduce the burden of proof on organizations to demonstrate service to specific communities in a way that feels tokenizing
Rethink funding criteria to be more inclusive of intersectional and multicultural organizations
Increase sustainable funding for dance and underrepresented art forms
Shift the responsibility for arts funding away from the general public and towards more systemic support
